comment.author: 92987904@N00
comment._content: This is the Woman Suffrage Parade, March 3, 1913, in Washington, DC, held the day before the inauguration of President Woodrow Wilson Marching for the Vote: Remembering the Woman Suffrage Parade of 1913 -- "The Woman Suffrage Parade of 1913, one of the most dramatic public events in the 82-year struggle of American women to gain the vote" (Guide from the Library of Congress)

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thank you Elizabeth! We'll fix the date in the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 31030327@N03
comment._content: My great aunt , K. Pearl Woodlief marched in this parade.  Being the only NC delegate, she carried the heavy NC flag throughout the parade.  She skipped work from the Durham, NC law firm where she was employed and when she telegraphed them on Monday morning, she was surprised to gain the support of the male lawyers of her firm.  She later worked with Alice Paul and others to establish a local chapter in NC and I still possess many of the letters she wrote to NC congressmen asking for their support.  She was born in Kittrell, NC in 1888.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: @eitherorr1 -- I hope you will consider giving your aunt's letters to the Library of Congress, or to an archive in North Carolina . . . .

comment.author: 74471476@N08
comment._content: I wonder if the Bain negative numbers could be used to put these pictures in sequential order. There is also this map of the order of marchers in the parade: www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/ppmsca.02946/

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: The Bain negative numbers may give a general idea of the sequence of images, but I don't think they can be used reliably to give the sequence of activities on a single day as in this case. Bain (or his staff) numbered these glass negatives after the fact, and we find that there are sometimes chronological anomalies, perhaps because a negative made much later was substituted for an earlier subject matter. (For a glimpse of operations in the Bain News Service office, see this image on the Library of Congress site: www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/ggbain.10071/. We're speculating that the boxes on the lower shelves may have held the glass negatives. The second-to-last number in the negative number string--e.g., 2505 in this case--may have been the number for a box of negatives.) Incidentally, we're coming up on the 100th anniversary of the march. Suffrage-centennial.org has posted plans for a re-enactment. There's an essay about the march (and the many materials in the Library of Congress that illuminate it) at: memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/aw01e/aw01e.html

comment.author: 74471476@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/barbara_loc] Barbara, Thanks for the additional information about the Bain News Service negatives. I wrote a brief account of the march and Wilson's inauguration using some of these photographs: susanbarsy.com/2013/03/03/1913-a-beginning-more-modern-th... The image of the Bain negative room was amazing--thanks!
